969277235961118722.text: 8/ Uncertainty is the hardest risk to underwrite but if things break your way then you will be rewarded by it because the rewards for a company unlocking a new market or changing consumer behavior can be huge.

969277167954571264.text: 7/ Most enterprise investment decisions center on quantifiable risk because most startups are going after known markets and/or known problems, but with new solutions. The investment decision is what amount of risk will you underwrite, and at what price?

969277048878374912.text: 6/ Possbilities and Uncertainties are related, but different. Possibility is, “I believe this can be a big thing,” and Uncertainty is, “I believe...but I have no freakin' idea how big this thing can be.”

969276985510801408.text: 5/ Uncertainties are often new markets, market expansion, or involve a consumer behavior change. Can you go from replacing taxis to redefining the future of all transportation? Is ephemeral messaging an enduring trend? Many consumer companies have high uncertainty risk.

969276938312327169.text: 4/ The third risk is Uncertainties, or unquantifiable risk. With probabilities, I can make an educated guess on market size and growth, but uncertainties are almost impossible to assign a number to.

969276842896064512.text: 3/ The second risk is Probabilities, or quantifiable risk. e.g. What is the probability you can build the tech, acquire users, hire a team, beat the competition? Different investors can look at the same company and come up with different probabilities and thus will differ.

969276715364052993.text: 2/ The first risk is Possibility. Is this idea for a company or product even possible? Do I believe the founder's vision or not? e.g. Self-driving cars? Strangers renting my sofa? Running my apps in someone else's data center? Find an investor that believes in your vision.

969276674364776448.text: 1/ I've been thinking lately about the different types of risk that VCs underwrite as investors. No framework is perfect but as an investor we need to judge each investment independently. For example, a security company will have less market risk than a crypto company.

1050053571578740736.text:
Rule #9: Evolve Your Culture. 
While the personalities of the founding team play a critical role in defining an organization’s culture, it is more accurate to say that an organization’s culture emerges over time based on the actions of many people, not just the founders.

1050053570727272449.text:
Rule #8: Raise Too Much Money.
“Excess” cash allows you to better account for the unforeseeable—and the only thing that’s foreseeable about blitzscaling is that you will at some point encounter the unforeseeable.

1050053569867468800.text:
Rule #7: Ignore Your Customers. 
The fundamental rule of customer service has long been “The customer is always right.” But for many blitzscalers, the key rule is “Provide whatever customer service you can as long as it doesn’t slow you down... and that may mean no service!”

1050053568986669056.text:
Rule #6: Do Things That Don’t Scale (Throwaway Work). 
A hack that takes a tenth of the time may be more useful than an elegantly engineered solution, even if it has to be thrown away later.

1050053567459938304.text:
Rule #5: Let Fires Burn. 
One of the ways that blitzscaling entrepreneurs can stay alive is by deciding to let certain fires burn so they can focus on the fires that, if allowed to rage unchecked, really will destroy the company.

1050053566574948352.text:
Rule #4: Launch a Product That Embarrasses You. 
Between (A) getting to market quickly with an imperfect product or (B) getting to market slowly with a “perfect” product, choose (A) nearly every time. Getting to market fast allows you to start getting the feedback to improve it.

1050053564880412673.text:
Rule #3: Practice “Bad” Management. 
When your org is growing 300% per year, you might have to promote people before they’re ready, and then swap them out if they sink rather than swim. You don’t have time to wait for things to “work out”. You have to act quickly and decisively.

1050053563982831616.text:
Rule #2: Hire Ms. Right Now, Not Ms. Right. 
You need managers and executives who are “just right” for the current phase of growth. After all, you won’t have to worry about that next phase if your team can’t actually get you there.

1050053562439360512.text:
Rule #1: Embrace Chaos. 
Traditional business strives for order and regularity in management, operations, and financial results. But when you're blitzscaling, the focus on order needs to be replaced with a willingness to embrace a level of chaos that would horrify most MBAs.
